title: Topeka Regional Airport
text:
Topeka Regional Airport , formerly known as Forbes Field, is a joint civil-military public <a href="airport">airport</a> owned by the Metropolitan Topeka Airport Authority in <a href="Shawnee%20County%2C%20Kansas">Shawnee County, Kansas</a>, seven miles south of downtown <a href="Topeka%2C%20Kansas">Topeka</a>, the <a href="capital%20city">capital city</a> of <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a>. The <a href="National%20Plan%20of%20Integrated%20Airport%20Systems">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems</a> for 2011–2015 <a href="FAA%20airport%20categories">called</a> it a "<a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>" airport.
Topeka Regional Airport is used by the <a href="University%20of%20Kansas">University of Kansas</a> (KU) for charter flights for its athletic teams and by schools visiting the KU campus in <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Kansas">Lawrence</a>, which is east of the airport via the <a href="Kansas%20Turnpike">Kansas Turnpike</a>. (<a href="Kansas%20City%20International%20Airport">Kansas City International Airport</a> is from KU.) The airport had scheduled airline service by multiple carriers until 2014.
<a href="Federal%20Aviation%20Administration">Federal Aviation Administration</a> records say the airport had 11,573 passenger boardings (enplanements) in <a href="calendar%20year">calendar year</a> 2019.
History.
Topeka Regional Airport (formerly Forbes Field) is on the site of the Topeka Army Airfield, later Forbes Air Force Base, a former <a href="Strategic%20Air%20Command">Strategic Air Command</a> (SAC) facility that transferred to <a href="Tactical%20Air%20Command">Tactical Air Command</a> in 1964 (while retaining <a href="Strategic%20Air%20Command">SAC</a>-gained tenants) and closed in 1973. Most of the former base administrative area is now used for offices and an industrial park. The <a href="190th%20Air%20Refueling%20Wing">190th Air Refueling Wing</a> (190 ARW) of the <a href="Kansas%20Air%20National%20Guard">Kansas Air National Guard</a> also uses part of the airport as an cantonment area and <a href="Air%20National%20Guard">Air National Guard</a> installation; the wing flies <a href="Boeing%20KC-135%20Stratotanker">Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker</a>s.
From 1942 to 1973 the following Air Force components supervised the airfield:
In April 1976, except for areas retained by the Air National Guard, most of the former Forbes Air Force Base was turned over to the city of Topeka and Shawnee County. During this transition, all airline flights moved from the <a href="Philip%20Billard%20Municipal%20Airport">Philip Billard Municipal Airport</a> to the newly-established Forbes Field. On June 1, 1976, the original <a href="Frontier%20Airlines%20%281950-1986%29">Frontier Airlines (1950-1986)</a> scheduled the first jet out of Forbes Field, a <a href="Boeing%20737-200">Boeing 737-200</a>. Shortly afterward, the <a href="Combat%20Air%20Museum">Combat Air Museum</a> was established on the airport.
In 1981 a bond to build a new air terminal was rejected, but approved in 1982. The $5 million terminal was completed in 1985.
The terminal has five airline ticket counters and two rental car counters. Currently Hertz is the only rental car company at FOE. There is one baggage claim carousel. Several charter and military flights use the terminal today.
In 2012 the MTAA Board of Directors renamed the facility to Topeka Regional Airport and Business Center, maintaining the name of the airfield as Forbes Field. Topeka Regional Airport is currently the home of the Kansas Air National Guard's 190th Air Refueling Wing and the 1st Battalion, <a href="108th%20Aviation%20Regiment">108th Aviation Regiment</a>, <a href="Kansas%20Army%20National%20Guard">Kansas Army National Guard</a>.
Historical airline service.
Airline service began in the early 1930s by a small mail carrier United States Airways which flew a route between Denver and Kansas City. Flights made stops in Goodland, Salina, and Topeka, Kansas, using a five-passenger <a href="Metal%20Aircraft%20Flamingo">Metal Aircraft Flamingo</a>. In the early 1940s, three new airlines began service, flying <a href="Douglas%20DC-3">Douglas DC-3</a> aircraft through the <a href="Philip%20Billard%20Municipal%20Airport">Philip Billard Municipal Airport</a> near downtown Topeka. <a href="Trans%20World%20Airlines">Trans World Airlines</a>, (<a href="TWA">TWA</a>), added Topeka as one of many stops on the carriers' transcontinental route between Los Angeles and New York. Topeka was a stop between Wichita and Kansas City. The carrier later upgraded to <a href="Martin%204-0-4">Martin 4-0-4</a> aircraft. <a href="Braniff%20International%20Airways">Braniff International Airways</a> added Topeka as one of many stops on their mainline route between Chicago and Houston. Topeka was also a stop between Kansas City and Wichita. <a href="Continental%20Airlines">Continental Airlines</a> added Topeka as a stop on a route between Denver and Kansas City which also included a stop at Salina, Kansas. <a href="Ozark%20Airlines">Ozark Airlines</a> also briefly served Topeka in the early 1950s with a route between Kansas City and Tulsa that stopped in Topeka and two other cities. Ozark and Braniff ended service in 1954, TWA ended in 1958 and Continental ended by 1960. <a href="Central%20Airlines">Central Airlines</a> began service in 1958 with DC-3s by picking up the routes to Kansas City and Wichita formerly operated by TWA and Braniff. The carrier then picked up Continental's route to Denver by 1960 using a <a href="Convair%20240">Convair 240</a> and became the only airline at Topeka. Central's service continued until the company merged with the original <a href="Frontier%20Airlines%20%281950-1986%29">Frontier Airlines</a> in 1967. Frontier then served Topeka using 50-seat <a href="Convair%20580">Convair 580</a> aircraft with nonstop flights to Kansas City as well as multi stop flights to Denver, St. Louis, and Wichita. Several air taxi and commuter airlines provided shuttle flights to Kansas City in the late 1960s and early 1970s, including <a href="Trans-Mo%20Airlines">Trans-Mo Airlines</a>, Allen Aviation, Air Associates Inc., and Shawnee Air Commuter.
After moving to the current Forbes Field in 1976, Topeka then saw multiple new carriers, some providing jet service:
<a href="Frontier%20Airlines%20%281950-1986%29">Frontier Airlines</a> upgraded their service with <a href="Boeing%20737-200">Boeing 737-200</a> jets direct to Kansas City, Denver, and Wichita, and added flights to <a href="O%27Hare%20International%20Airport">Chicago O'hare International Airport</a> with a stop in Lincoln, Nebraska. In the early 1980s, Frontier also operated nonstop jets to Manhattan, KS, and Joplin, MO. The carrier introduced the <a href="McDonnell%20Douglas%20MD80">McDonnell Douglas MD80</a> jet to Topeka shortly before ending all service in 1984.
Capitol Air Service began shuttle flights to Kansas City, Manhattan, and Salina, Kansas, around 1970. From 1987 through 1989, the carrier had a codeshare agreement with the new <a href="Braniff%20%281983-1990%29">Braniff</a> Airways and operated as Braniff Express. Capitol Air flew <a href="Cessna%20402">Cessna 402</a> and <a href="de%20Havilland%20Canada%20DHC-6%20Twin%20Otter">de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter</a> aircraft and shut down about the time of the Braniff collapse in 1989.
Trans Central Airlines provided commuter flights to Oklahoma City and onto Dallas/Fort Worth in 1981 and 1982 using <a href="Fairchild%20Swearingen%20Metroliner">Fairchild Swearingen Metroliner</a> aircraft.
The original <a href="Midway%20Airlines%20%281976-1991%29">Midway Airlines</a>, provided <a href="Douglas%20DC-9-10">Douglas DC-9-10</a> jet service to <a href="Chicago%20Midway%20International%20Airport">Chicago Midway International Airport</a> with a stop in Kansas City from 1982 through 1985. Up to three flights per day were operated.
<a href="United%20Airlines">United Airlines</a> provided mainline jet service in 1986 and 1987 with three daily flights to the carrier's hub at Denver, making one stop at Kansas City or Wichita, and one daily flight to Chicago O'Hare making one stop in Lincoln. <a href="Boeing%20727">Boeing 727</a> and <a href="Boeing%20737">Boeing 737</a> jets were used.
<a href="Air%20Midwest">Air Midwest</a> began commuter flights to Kansas City in 1981 using <a href="Fairchild%20Swearingen%20Metroliner">Fairchild Swearingen Metroliner</a> II aircraft. Air Midwest went on to operate several codeshare services with major airlines, the first being with <a href="Eastern%20Airlines">Eastern Airlines</a> in 1985. Air Midwest operated as <a href="Eastern%20Express">Eastern Express</a> feeding Eastern's hub at Kansas City until 1988 when Eastern dismantled the Kansas City hub operation. By then Braniff had established a hub at Kansas City and Air Midwest became a Braniff Express feeder carrier along with Capitol Air. Within a year Braniff had shut down and Air Midwest reverted to operating under their own branding at Kansas City. Air Midwest also had codeshare agreements with other major airlines, including one with TWA at that carrier's hub in St. Louis. In late 1989, Air Midwest began nonstop flights from Topeka to St. Louis operating as <a href="Trans%20World%20Express">Trans World Express</a> while discontinuing its flights to Kansas City. <a href="British%20Aerospace%20Jetstream%2031">British Aerospace Jetstream 31</a> aircraft were used. This service ended in early 1991 as Air Midwest established yet another codeshare agreement at Kansas City with <a href="US%20Airways">US Airways</a>. Flights to Kansas City were restored, now as <a href="US%20Airways%20Express">US Airways Express</a> using <a href="Beechcraft%201900">Beechcraft 1900</a> aircraft. This service was long term and continued until Air Midwest ended Topeka service in November, 2003. Air Midwest had the only service at Topeka from 1989 through 2003. 
The 1980s were the boom years for traffic at Forbes Field as the airport handled up to 180,000 passengers per year. By the 1990s however, the airport saw a dramatic drop in traffic and scheduled passenger service became subsidized by the <a href="Essential%20Air%20Service">Essential Air Service</a> program. This subsidized service ended in May, 2003, due to federal law prohibiting a subsidy over $200 per passenger for airports within 210 miles of the nearest large or medium hub airport (<a href="Kansas%20City%20International%20Airport">Kansas City International Airport</a>, a medium hub, is 71 miles away). This caused the final carrier, Air Midwest dba US Airways Express, to end service.
After three years with no service, <a href="Allegiant%20Air">Allegiant Air</a> came to Topeka in 2006 with nonstop jet flights to <a href="McCarran%20International%20Airport">Las Vegas</a> on two days per week. The carrier used <a href="McDonnell%20Douglas%20MD80">McDonnell Douglas MD80</a>s but ended service on July 30, 2007. One last effort to revive scheduled airline service was made when <a href="United%20Express">United Express</a>, operated by <a href="ExpressJet">ExpressJet</a>, began flights on January 7, 2014, with two daily <a href="Embraer%20ERJ%20family">Embraer-145</a> regional jets nonstop to Chicago's <a href="O%27Hare%20International%20Airport">O'Hare International Airport</a>. The service only lasted eight months however and ceased on September 2, 2014.
Facilities.
Topeka Regional Airport covers 2,854 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (1,155 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an <a href="elevation">elevation</a> of 1,078 feet (329 m) above <a href="mean%20sea%20level">mean sea level</a>. It has two concrete <a href="runway">runway</a>s: 13/31 is 12,803 by 200 feet (3,902 x 61 m) and 3/21 is 7,001 by 150 feet (2,134 x 46 m).
In the year ending October 31, 2017 the airport had 22,418 aircraft operations, average 61 per day: 65% military, 32% <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>, 3% <a href="air%20taxi">air taxi</a>, and <1% airline. 36 aircraft were then based at this airport: 25% single-engine, 14% multi-engine, 11% jet, and 50% military.
Airlines and destinations.
The airport has had no airline service since September 2, 2014.
